abstract: The Guggenheim Museum has entered into a licensing agreement with a Vermont company that produces high-end commercial paints to create 200 interior and exterior wall colors drawn from well-known paintings in the museum's collection and from wall colors that curators, artists and designers have used for exhibitions there.
snippet: The Guggenheim Museum has entered into a licensing agreement with a Vermont company that produces high-end commercial paints to create 200 interior and exterior wall colors drawn from well-known paintings in the museum's collection and from wall...
lead_paragraph: House paint has been a part of the modernist fine-art supply cabinet for more than a century, from Picasso to Pollock to Bridget Riley. Now, the Guggenheim Museum is hoping to generate a little revenue by turning the phenomenon back in the other direction. The museum has entered into a licensing agreement with Fine Paints of Europe, a Vermont company that produces high-end commercial paints,to create a set of 200 interior and exterior wall colors drawn from well-known paintings in the Guggenheim's collection and from wall colors that curators, artists and designers (including Frank Lloyd Wright himself) have used for exhibitions over several decades.
